user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BSP_ExecTput:
```c
static void OS_BSP_ExecTput(const char *cap, const char *param)
{
    pid_t cpid;
    int   status;

    cpid = fork();
    if (cpid < 0)
    {
        return;
    }
    if (cpid == 0)
    {
        execlp("tput", "tput", cap, param, NULL);
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }
    waitpid(cpid, &status, 0);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragment in the function modifies either of the function parameters (cap or param). Specifically:
- There are no assignments to cap or param, no pointer arithmetic, no increment/decrement, and no passing of their addresses (e.g., &cap or &param) that could allow the pointer variables themselves to be altered.
- The parameters are declared as const char * so the function cannot legally modify the objects they point to through those pointers within this function.
- The only use of the parameters is to pass them by value to execlp; passing a pointer by value does not modify the pointer parameter itself. Although execlp takes varargs for the argv strings, that is a call that copies the pointer values into the called function — it does not change the pointer variables in this function.
- Other calls (fork, exit, waitpid) do not modify the function parameters.
Therefore no fragment requires investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 (a function parameter should not be modified).
